fields.answer: Lateral Hemisection of spinal cord.

fields.question: Lhermittes sign?
fields.answer: On flexion of neck there is electric shock like sensation that radiates to back and neck. Seen in MS, Cervical Spondylosis, neck Irrad.

fields.question: Orthostatic Hypotension?
fields.answer: reduction in SBP by 20mm or DBP by 10mm within 3 min of standing or head tilt in tilt table.

fields.question: Plummer-Vinson syndrome?
fields.answer: Risk factor for SCC of UGI, common in middle aged women

fields.question: Achalasia
fields.answer: Malignancy can mimic achalasia, so do endoscopy to rule out obstruction. Achalasia results from degeneration of neurons in Aurbachs plexus.

fields.question: Zenker Diverticulum?
fields.answer: Cervical outpouching of oesoophagus through cricopharyngeous muscle.

fields.question: Boerhaeve syndrome?
fields.answer: transmural esophageal tear + Mediastinitis.

fields.question: Mallory weiss tear?
fields.answer: Superficial tear in acute alcohol intoxication.

fields.question: A 53-year-old woman with a history of carcinoid tumor of the appendix (status post resection) presents to a local clinic with symmetric, dry, hyperpigmented skin lesions and persistent diarrhea. Her husband expresses concern that the patient does not seem to be herself anymore; he reports that she has been irritable, confused, and forgetful. What is the most likely diagnosis?
fields.answer: Pellagra, a deficiency of vitamin B3 (niacin), 2° to a recurrent carcinoid tumor. Carcinoid tumors produce serotonin, which is a derivative of tryptophan. However, tryptophan is also the precursor of niacin. In patients with carcinoid tumors, the tumor can be so active that most tryptophan is used for serotonin production, resulting in niacin deficiency.

fields.question: x-ray small bowel obstruction?
fields.answer: Abdominal films demonstrate a stepladder pattern of dilated small-bowel loops, air-fluid levels and a paucity of gas in the colon.

fields.question: Tt of Wilsons disease?
fields.answer: Dietary copper restriction (avoid shellfish, liver, legumes), penicil­ lamine (a copper chelator that 1' urinary copper excretion), and zinc (1' fecal excretion).

fields.question: Wilson disease?
fields.answer: Autosomal recessive, KF rings in descment membrane of cornea, presents before 30yrs of age, 50% are symptomatic by age 15.   Patient presents with hepatitis, neurological dysfunction(tremor), psychiatric abnormalities(anxiety, depression).

fields.question: Primary biliary cirrhosis?
fields.answer: An autoimmune disorder characterized by destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. Most commonly presents in middle-aged women with other autoimmune conditions.

fields.question: Treatment of Chronic Hep B?
fields.answer: Chronic HBV infection: Interferon and lamivudine (3TC) or adefovir.

fields.question: A 2 1 -year-old male college student in the midst of final exams presents to a local clinic with "yellow eyes:' His physical examination is unremarkable except for scleral icterus, and a CBC and blood smear show no abnormalities. A comprehensive metabolic profile reveals a normal AST and ALT but elevated unconjugated bilirubin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
fields.answer: Gilbert's syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder of bilirubin glucuronidation due to J- activity of the enzyme glucuronyl transferase. Patients present with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia but have a normal CBC, blood smear, and LFTs. The condition is benign, and no treatment is indicated.

fields.question: Approach to cholestasis
fields.answer: img:

fields.question: Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis?
fields.answer: An idiopathic disorder characterized by progressive inflammation and fibrosis accompanied by strictures of extra- and intrahepatic bile ducts. The disease usually presents in young males with ulcerative colitis. Patients are at I risk for cholangiocarcinoma.  Liver biopsy reveals pericluctal sclerosis ("onion skinning").

fields.question: Gall stone ileus?
fields.answer: A mechanical obstruction resulting from the passage ofa large (> 2.5-cm) stone into the bowel through a cholecystoduoclenal fistula. Obstruction is often at the ileocecal valve.  AXR with characteristics of SBO and pneumobilia (gas in the biliary tree) confirms the diagnosis. Upper GI barium contrast images vvill dem­ onstrate no contrast in the colon. Tx: Laparotomy with stone extraction; closure of the fistula and cholecys­tectomy.

fields.question: Charcots triad and Reynold Pentad?
fields.answer: Charcot's triad-RUQ pain, jaundice, and fever/chills-is classic, Reynold pentad: Charcot triad + shock and altered mental status.

fields.question: Risk factors for gall stones?
fields.answer: 4F's, OCP use, rapid weight loss, chronic hemolysis (pigment stones in sickle cell disease), small bowel resection (loss of enterohepatically circulated bile), and TPN.

The headache that precedes or accompanies SAH is often described as a “thunderclap” headache, meaning that it reaches its maximum intensity in seconds. This description is unusual in migraine (where the headache usually reaches maximum inten￾sity in 5-30 minutes) and mandates CT scanning or lumbar puncture

When syncope occurs in an older patient as a result of head turning, wearing a tight shirt collar, or shaving over the neck area, carotid sinus hypersensitivity should be considered. It usually occurs in men above the age of 50

All patients with suspected multiple sclerosis should have an MR of the brain. MR is sensitive in defining demyeli￾nating lesions in the brain and spinal cord.
Lower motor neuron signs include focal weakness, focal wasting, and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron signs include an extensor plantar response and an increased tendon reflex in a weakened muscle.

Most (75%) are adenocarcinomas in the head of the pancreas. Risk factors include smoking, chronic pancreatitis, and a first-degree relative with pancre­ atic cancer. Incidence 1' after age 45; slightly more common in males.

l0 hemochromatosis: An autosomal recessive disease characterized by mutations in the HFE gene that result in excessive absorption of dietary Iron. 2° hemochromatosis: Occurs in patients receiving chronic transfusion therapy (eg, a-thalassemia).
A transferrin saturation (serum iron divided by TIBC) > 45% is highly sug­ gestive of iron overload.

The sequelae of chronic hepatitis include cirrhosis, liver failure, and hepatocellular carcinoma.
Hepatitis serological markers:
Chronic hepatitis: ALT and AST are persistently elevated for > 3-6 months.
An AST/ALT ratio > 2 suggests alcohol hepatitis: you're toASTed.
HCV is Chronic; 60-70% of patients with HCV infection will develop chronic hepatitis.

Risk factors for colorectal carcinoma?
Iron deficiency anemia in an elderly patient is colorectal cancer until proven otherwise.
diverticulosis is out pouching of mucosa or submucosa into muscularis layer, if that out pouching is infected or inflamed, condition is called diverticulitis.
Colonoscopy is definitive diagnosis in diverticular diseases, Avoid sigmoidoscopy/colonoscopy in patients with early diverticulitis in view of the risk of perforation .
If there is h/o vomiting in migraine, it is better to give parentral or nasal triptans instead of oral triptans.
Patients who use medications for headache more than twice weekly are at risk of medication overuse headache.
In many metabolic neuropathies, the longest nerve fibers are affected first, lead￾ing to the stocking-glove pattern of sensory loss. Autonomic changes can accompany the sensory loss.
EMG with nerve conduction velocity testing will categorize neuropathy into axonal and demyelinating varieties and will often provide important diagnostic information.
In vitamin B12 deficiency, posterior column function (eg, vibratory sen￾sation) would be affected out of proportion to small pain and temperature fibers.
the relaxation phase of muscle stretch reflexes is delayed in hypothyroidism, thyroid deficiency does not cause a sensory neuropathy.
Mul￾tiple sclerosis (which can cause oligoclonal bands) is an upper motor neuron disease that would not cause distal weakness or hyporeflexia.
Myasthenia gravis does not affect sensation or reflexes.
Mononeuritis mul￾tiplex causes asymmetric signs, usually with sensory loss, and does not affect swallowing.
